data.title: What Happened in November 1988
data.meta_description: What happened in November 1988. Browse historical events, famous birthdays and notable deaths from Nov 1988 or search by date, day or keyword.
data.text:
Historical Events

Staten Island ferry gets 1st pay phones

Sports History

A's shortstop Walt Weiss wins AL rookie of year; 3rd straight for Oakland; Jose Canseco 1986, Mark McGwire 1987

Radio History

Mexican radio station erroneously reports Mike Tyson had died in car crash

Nov 2 The Morris worm, the first internet-distributed computer worm to gain mainstream media attention is launched from MIT, strikes Pentagon, SDI research lab and six universities

Pakistan claims it downed Afghan warplane

Event of Interest

President Reagan signs credit-card disclosure-bill

Nov 3 Soviet Union agrees to allow teaching of Hebrew

Film & TV History

Talk-show host Geraldo Rivera's nose is broken as Roy Innis brawls with skinheads at TV taping

First NBA game at Charlotte Coliseum - Hornets lose to Cavs, 133-93

"Kokomo" single by The Beach Boys from the film "Cocktail" goes to #1

Nov 5 "Kokomo", single by the Beach Boys from the film "Cocktail" tops the charts, their first hit in 20 years, and to date their latest

Nov 5 1st NBA game at Bradley Center, Milw Bucks lose to Atlnata Hawks 94-107

Nov 5 1st NBA game at Miami Arena, Miami Heat loss to LA Clippers, 111-91

Nov 5 1st NBA game at Palace of Auburn Hills, Pistons beat Hornets 94-85

Nov 5 Breeders' Cup Horse Racing, Churchill Downs; winners: Alysheba, Gt Communicator, Gulch, Is It True, Miesque, Open Mind, Personal Ensign

Nov 5 Cornell confirms grad student source of worst computer sabotage

Nov 5 France performs nuclear test

Nov 5 Gulch wins Breeder's Cup

Nov 5 Japan beats MLB all stars 2-1 in Tokyo (Game 1 of 7)

Japan & MLB all stars played to a 6-6 draw (Game 2 of 7)

19th NYC Marathon

Steve Jones wins 19th NYC men's marathon (2:08:20); Grete Waitz wins record 9th women's title

MLB all stars beats Japan 16-8 (Game 3 of 7)

Leonard vs. LaLonde

Sugar Ray Leonard KO's Donnie LaLonde

900 die as earthquake hits China

Nov 8 Arco Arena in Sacramento, California, opens, Sac Kings lose to Seattle, 97-75

Election of Interest

Joe Lieberman is elected to the United States Senate as a Democrat, defeating incumbent Lowell Weicker

Nov 8 Rafael Fernandez Colón re-elected Governor of Puerto Rico

Bush vs. Dukakis

Vice President George H. W. Bush is elected President of the United States, defeating Democrat candidate Michael Dukakis

Don Sebesky and Gloria Nissenson's musical "Prince of Central Park", starring Jo Anne Worley opens at Belasco Theater, NYC; runs for 4 performances

Nov 9 MLB All-Star team beat Japan 8-2 in Nishinomya, (Game 4 of 7)

China confirms earthquake death toll will rise above current 938

Nov 10 MLB All-Star team beats Japan 3-1 in Tokyo (Game 5 of 7)

Nov 10 NY's MTA announces it may replace tokens with credit card type passes

Hershiser Wins Cy Young

Orel Hershiser (23-8) is a unanimous choice as NL Cy Young Award

Oldest known insect fossils (390 million yrs) reported in Science

Japan beats MLB All-Star team 5-4 in Tokyo (Game 6 of 7)

Nov 12 USSR performs nuclear test at the Semipalatinsk Test Site in northeast Kazakhstan

Ayrton Senna

Brazilian McLaren driver Ayrton Senna finishes 2nd in the season ending Australian Grand Prix in Adelaide to win his first Formula 1 World Drivers Championship; wins title by 3 points from Alain Prost

Sitcom "Murphy Brown" starring Candice Bergen premieres on CBS

91 m radio telescope dish at Green Bank, WV, collapses

Nov 15 Dodgers outfielder Kirk Gibson wins NL MVP Award

Nov 15 Soviet space shuttle makes unmanned maiden flight (2 orbits)

Nov 15 The first Fairtrade label, Max Havelaar, is launched in the Netherlands.

Estonia declares sovereignty in internal affairs

Canseco AL MVP

Jose Canseco is 1st unanimous AL MVP since Reggie Jackson

Benazir Bhutto

Pakistan's Benazir Bhutto's PPP wins 1st free Pakistani elections in 11 years

Reagan Hosts Thatcher

President Reagan and the First Lady participate in the official state arrival ceremony, meetings and a state dinner with Margaret Thatcher

Nov 16 President Reagan meets with Jerusalem's mayor Teddy Kollek

Nov 16 Robin Givens sues Mike Tyson for $125 million for libel

Linda Petursdottir of Iceland, 18, crowned 38th Miss World

Rumours

Neil Simon's "Rumors" premieres in NYC

NASCAR CUP

38th NASCAR Sprint Cup: Bill Elliott wins

Sabatini Wins WTA

Argentine tennis star Gabriela Sabatini beats Pam Shriver 7–5, 6–2, 6–2 to win her first WTA Tour Championship at Madison Square Garden, NYC

Nov 20 Boston College beats Army 38-24 in the 'Emerald isle Classic' at Dublin's Lansdowne Road Stadium, the first NCAA American Football game to be played in Europe

France performs nuclear test

Nov 23 President Reagan announces that he is pocket-vetoing a bill designed to further restrict lobbying by former federal employees.

Gretzky Gets 600

Wayne Gretzky scores his 600th NHL goal

Nov 23 Yankees sign free agent 2nd-baseman Steve Sax to 3-year contract

53rd Iron Bowl: Auburn beats Alabama 15-10 in Birmingham

Nov 25 Convention on exploitation of Antarctic mineral resources signed

Nov 25 German politician Rita Süssmuth becomes president of the Bundestag.

Chuck Berry

Rock guitar legend Chuck Berry (62) pays $250 fine to resolve NYC assault charges

Nov 25 US & Soviet chess grand masters Donaldson & Akhmilovskaya wed

Nov 25 Widespread earthquake hits North East US, Canada, no damage reported

Alexander Volkov, Sergei Krikalev & Jean-Loup Chretien launch

Nov 26 Pioneer 6's closest approach to Earth since 1965 launch (1.87 M km)

CFL Grey Cup, Landsdowne Park, Ottawa: Winnipeg Blue Bombers edge BC Lions, 22-21; first Grey Cup game won by a team with only a .500 season

Acrobat & Harlequin

Picasso's "Acrobat & Harlequin" sells for $38.46 million

Cyclone lashes Bangladesh, Eastern India; 317 killed

Nov 30 France performs nuclear test at Fangataufa Island

Nov 30 Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co. buys RJR Nabisco for $25.07 billion USD.

Nov 30 NYC furrier sues Mike Tyson for $92,000 for non payment of purchase

Nov 30 Soviets stop jamming Radio Liberty; 1st time in 38 yrs

Nov 30 UN General Assembly (151-2) censures US for refusing PLO's Arafat visa

Famous Birthdays

Masahiro Tanaka, Japanese baseball pitcher (MLB All Star 2014, 19; 6×NPB All-Star; NY Yankees), born in Itami, Hyōgo

Julia Görges, German tennis player (7 WTA, 6 ITF titles), born in Bad Oldesloe, Schleswig-Holstein

Nov 2 Lindze Letherman, American actress (General Hospital), born in Fresno, California

Angus McLaren, Australian Actor

Dez Bryant, American football wide receiver (Dallas Cowboys), born in Galveston County, Texas

Virat Kohli

Indian cricketer, star batsman and captain of India (2013-), born in Delhi, India

Conchita Wurst [Thomas Neuwirth], Austrian singer and drag queen (Eurovision Song Contest winner: 2014), born in Gmunden, Austria

Emma Stone

American actress (The Amazing Spider-Man, La La Land), born in Scottsdale, Arizona

Nov 6 Erik Lund, Swedish footballer, born in Ljungskile, Sweden

Elsa Hosk, Swedish model (Victoria's Secret), born in Stockholm, Sweden

Nov 7 Tinie Tempah [Patrick Chukwuemeka Okogwu], British rapper ("Written In The Stars"), born in Plumstead, London

Nikki Blonsky, American actress, born in Great Neck, New York

Chisaki Hama [Rika Izumi], Japanese actress and model, born in Kyoto, Japan

Alexandra Kyle, American actress, born in Los Angeles, California

Russell Westbrook, American basketball guard (NBA MVP 2017; NBA All-Star Game MVP 2015, 16; OKC Thunder, Houston Rockets, LA Lakers, LA Clippers), born in Long Beach, California

B.o.B [Bobby Simmons], American rapper and record producer ("Nothin' on You"; "Airplanes"), born in Winston-Salem, North Carolina

Justin Cooper, American actor (Liar, Liar, General Hospital), born in Los Angeles, California

Jeffrey Jordan, American college basketball player; son of Michael Jordan

Nov 18 Montanna Thompson, English actress (The Story of Tracy Beaker), born in Islington, England

Patrick Kane

American ice hockey player (Chicago Blackhawks), born in Buffalo, New York

Suresh Guptara and Jyoti Guptara, British-Indian novelists

Abby Phillip, American political commentator (CNN), born in Alexandria, Virginia

Hafþór Júlíus Björnsson, Icelandic weightlifter (World's Strongest Man 2018; deadlifting WR 501kg 2020) and actor ("The Mountain" Game of Thrones), born in Reykjavík, Iceland

Nov 26 Yumi Kobayashi, Japanese fashion model, born in Tokyo

Christopher Stringini, American pop singer (US5), born in Wheaton, Illinois

Nov 28 Scarlett Pomers, American actress

Russell Wilson

American NFL quarterback (Super Bowl 2013, Seattle Seahawks; Pro Bowl 2012–15, 2017–19), born in Cincinnati, Ohio

Phillip Hughes, Australian cricketer who died in cricket accident, born in Macksville, Australia (d. 2014)

Famous Weddings

Jeff Goldblum

American actor Jeff Goldblum (36) weds American actress Geena Davis (32) in Las Vegas; separate in 1990; divorce finalized in 1991

LA Law's Corbin Bernsen marries actress Amanda Pays

Famous Deaths

Henri van Praag, Dutch para-psychologist, dies

John Hubbard, American actor (Don't Call Me Charlie, The Tall T, One Million B.C.), dies of kidney failure at 74

Hans Baumann, German nationalist writer, dies at 74

Kingman Brewster, American educator and president of Yale University, dies at 69

Billy Curtis, 4'2" actor (Terror of Tiny Town), dies at 79

Nov 9 Clarke Hinkle, American College-Pro Football HOF utility (NFL C'ship 1936, 39; 7 × First-team All-Pro; NFL All-Star 1938–40; GB Packers), dies at 79

Nov 9 David Bauer, Canadian Hockey Hall of Fame player and builder (priest, school coach; National Team manager), dies at 64

Nov 9 John Mitchell, American lawyer, political operative (US Attorney General, 1969-72), and convicted perjurer (Watergate Scandal), dies of heart attack in Washington, DC at 75

William Ifor Jones, Welsh organist and conductor, dies at 88

Tomasz Sikorski, Polish minimalist composer (Solitude of Sounds), dies at 49

Antal Doráti, Hungarian-American conductor (Minneapolis Symphony, 1949-1960), dies at 82

Nov 13 Jaromír Vejvoda, Czech composer (Beer Barrel Polka), dies at 86

Mona Washbourne, actress (Blue Bird, Games), dies at 84

Lotte Stam-Beese, German-Dutch architect and urban planner who helped reconstruct Rotterdam after the war, dies at 85

Sheilah Graham, gossip columnist, dies of heart failure at 84

Christina Onassis, Greek heiress, daughter of Aristotle Onassis, dies of heart failure at 37

Carl Hubbell

American Baseball Hall of Fame pitcher (9 × MLB All-Star; World Series 1933; NL MVP 1933, 36; NY Giants), dies at 85

Erich Fried, Austrian-British writer, dies at 67

Nov 22 Janet Ertel, crooner, dies

Nov 22 Luis Barragán, Mexican architect (Casa Luis Barragán; Pritzker Prize - 1980), dies at 86

Raymond Dart

Australian paleoanthropologist (Australopithecus africanus), dies at 95 [1]

Irmgard Seefried, German soprano, dies at 69

Antonio Estévez, Venezuelan composer and conductor (Cantata Criolla), dies at 72

Nov 26 Bent Peter Rasch, Danish canoeist (Olympic gold C-2 1000m 1952), dies at 54

Angela Aames, actress (Lost Empire, Basic Training), dies

Nov 27 Jan Hein Donner, Dutch chess grand master, dies at 61

Nov 27 John Carradine, American actor (The Grapes of Wrath, Stagecoach, Howling), dies of kidney failure at 82

Nov 27 Karel Horky, Czech composer, dies at 79

Charlie Rouse, American hard bop jazz tenor saxophonist (Thelonious Monk Quartet; Sphere), dies of lung cancer at 64
